d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (03:21): h.264 is an impressive piece of work.
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (03:21): (Morning, all)
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (03:22): btw, it's impressively slow on a celeron with 128k cache too :)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:22): it is, but too intensive for SPARC in any case, not without a load of optimizations.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:22): I've had fairly decent luck with it on my EM64Ts, though.
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (03:23): 2.1GHz Athlon64 (512k cache) is about 4-5x faster than a 2.4GHz celeron (128k cache) at decoding.. ;)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:23): what extensions to Pentium 4 Celerons have?
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (03:24): sse1+2 for instance
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (03:24): but it's netburst + too little cache that kills performance.. similar cpu but with 512k cache is much better..
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:29): hmm, finally got my SGD server at home accessible from school (which blocks >= 1024). Gotta love SSH port forwarding.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:29): Stric: athlon has much lower memory latency which improves H.264 decoding a lot, too.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:29): which also killed two birds with one stone -- no need for SSL.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:29): however there are commerial decoders for H.264 which work in realtime for H.264.
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (03:29): delewis, yeap forward over port 443, then you usually can get through the most stringent firewalls.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:30): erm
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:30): I mean blade1000
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:30): (as long you have a UltraSPARC-IIIcu)

53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:31): jamesd: I'm doing something similar. I specified in the SGD server configuration that the client should connect to port localhost:7777, and then I use ssh to port forward localhost:7777 to solnetworks.net:777, which is NAT'd to my SGD server's port 3144 (the SGD unencrypted default port)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:32): and I do something similar with for SGD's HTTP server, which normally sends the login/password in cleartext.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:33): nrubsig: have some links or names of these commercial decoders for UltraSPARC-III?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:33): I'd be interested in getting my hands on one.

7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (03:34): delewis, i solved it by   having  external addresss   sdg.blah.net   show up as 127.0.0.1   then make  tunnel   local port   3144  to  the sgd box that uses an internal nameserver that knows where the box really is.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:34): delewis: AFAIK our old homepage at GMD has some links.

53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:34): SGD is fairly nice, though, and I was really surprised at the performance I was getting from it over an encapsulated SSH connection (using blowfish, of course)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:35): keep in mind, my upload bandwidth (on the SGD server) is about 15KB/s

6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:35): delewis: note that this software is not really ultrasparc specific by design, it is just "optimizsed" at source level with some tweaks for UltraSPARC because one of the authors is a ex-sun employee.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:36): delewis: note that there are H.264 decoders written in java, too. and they work quite nice on a blade2500
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:36): even at full DVD resolution
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:36): interesting.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:37): the x264 implementation is basically unusable on anything less than a 2GHz x86.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:37): yeah, but it uses multiple threads to use more than one CPU
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:37): delewis: are you using one of the sample implementations ?
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (03:37): a 1280x720/30fps h264 takes around 60% cpu on my athlon64 @ 2.1GHz with mplayer
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (03:38): about 250% on the cel2.4 ;)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:38): well, actually, I'm not sure what the performance is like when decoding.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:38): I'm mostly familiar with the performance associated with encoding H.264
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:38): delewis: encoders are a completely different thing.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:38): nrubsig: what's the performance like with some of the commercial encoders?
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:39): *shrug*
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:40): I'm getting about 15fps on my UltraSPARC-III (non-CU) encoding MPEG4.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:40): of course, that's only using a single CPU
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:43): delewis: did you compile the source yourself ?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:45): nrubsig: of course.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:45): delewis: try -xipo=2
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:45): with studio 11
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:46): ffmpeg/mplayer won't build with Sun Studio (well, it could, if you removed the GCCisms)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (03:46): and the fact that this was built with gcc on SPARC probably explains some of the poor performance.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:46): yeah
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (03:46): what's the purpose of xipo=2 ?
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (03:47): delewis: ffmpeg does, mplayer i dont think it's worth the trouble :-)
62115b1ea90366cbcce7a495fa28cbce (03:47): inter-procedural optimizations? (just guessing)
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:47): but 15fps is not that bad for encoding.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:47): elektronkind: it takes the whole source and optimizes it as one piece, even doing inlinking across source files.
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:48): er
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:48): inlining
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:48): elektronkind: why ?
b4e23593ef02e114f30b5b85761fe1e4 (03:48): I didn't mean that in a bad way :)
6c728b2ae6e0bdb14ac212ed5f74c1d8 (03:48): elektronkind: combine it with profile-feedback and you get faster executables.
6fb06278f0acad5116524cf789d291c2 (03:49): xine decodes dvd's with ffmpeg and performance is very good (CPU usage a little high 38%)
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (03:59): delewis: tried that gcc with sunpro backend already?
